citing_paper_authors: Joel, Martin | Howard, Johnson | Benoit, Farley | Anna, Maclachlan
raw_text: The algorithm used to align English-Inuktitut sentences is an extension of that presented in Gale and Church (1993) .It does not identify crossing alignments where the sentence order within paragraphs in the parallel texts differs. Sentence alignments typically involve one English sentence matching one Inuktitut sentence (a 1-to-1 bead), but may also involve 2-to-1, 1-to-2, 0-to-1, 1-to-0 and 2-to-2 sentence matching patterns, or beads
clean_text: The algorithm used to align English-Inuktitut sentences is an extension of that presented in Gale and Church (1993).

citing_paper_authors: Stefan, Bott | Horacio, Saggion
raw_text: The problem of sentence alignment was first tack led in the context of statistical machine translation. Gale and Church (1993) proposed a dynamic programming algorithm for the sentence-level alignment of translations that exploited two facts: the length of translated sentences roughly corresponds to the length of the original sentences and the sequence of sentences in translated text largely corresponds to the original order of sentences
clean_text: Gale and Church (1993) proposed a dynamic programming algorithm for the sentence-level alignment of translations that exploited two facts: the length of translated sentences roughly corresponds to the length of the original sentences and the sequence of sentences in translated text largely corresponds to the original order of sentences.

clean_text: we used a slightly modified version of CharAlign described by Gale and Church (1993).
